🏆2020 Clarkston High School #SeniorAwards have been announced and #TeamRUSH27 is super #RUSHProud of Logan for being recognized with the CHS Engineering Department’s #EngineeringAward!

Mrs. Laura Kalinowski, who leads the department, had this to say “[Logan] has gone above and beyond expectations in the classroom. His projects were always full of creativity and he was thoughtful of the technicalities. It has been a pleasure to be Logan’s teacher the last 3 years and I’m so happy to honor him with our Engineering Department Award.”

Over his four years on Team RUSH, Logan has demonstrated these qualities and more in the shop, 3D printer lab, and in the #RUSHPit. He grew into numerous key roles that the team relied on, including machining parts on the CNC machines, CAD design work, robot repair/maintenance, and training others. His dedication, focus to detail, and #RUSHSpirit have been second to none. Congrats, Logan!

#WeAreTeamRUSH #WeAreClarkston

Susan Mohr from CHS is in the spotlight today! In the words of her student, Sierra Waitkus:
.

Today we published the results of the Virtual At-Home Learning surveys on our website (https://www.clarkston.k12.mi.us/surveys). We were pleased to see that 1,056 parents and 506 students responded to our surveys. As you can see in the reports, the vast majority of CCS families are participating in at-home learning, and are finding that it offers "just enough" in all areas. Overall, our community is satisfied with the education and support they are receiving from our district.

Our teacher survey reports reveal that while teachers feel equipped to lead at-home learning, they still worry about their students' academic growth and are seeking greater engagement with families during these challenging times. These results are based on the responses of 314 teachers.

We are working to continue to strengthen the Clarkston Virtual At-Home Learning model and once again, thank all who participated in our Check-Up Surveys.

Despite the challenges of this unprecedented time, the students, staff, and families of Independence Elementary have used their powers of love and kindness to continue a very special 17-year Independence Elementary tradition - the annual IE all-school Clarkston Academic Service Learning #clarkstonasl project, S.O.C.K.S. ("Serving Our Community Kid Style")!

The IE staff, led by first-grade teacher Anne Duffy, did not want to see this treasured tradition come to an end due to the school shut down. With the help of our staff and community, Anne reached out to hospitals, local businesses, and families to see how the IE family could continue to serve our community as a school - all from home. She created an amazing opportunity for our students, staff, and family to serve for a week!

S.O.C.K.S week is this week, April 20-24. So far, IE staff and students have reached out to support healthcare heroes and other essential workers, and today, Earth Day, they've already worked hard to "Clean Up! Cheer Up!" our community. Check it out!

In order to support our teachers' continued professional growth and learning specifically related to the understanding the whole child and social emotional learning supports, NSE Kindergarten teachers, Abbey St. Aubin and Anne Marie Hart, along with Special Education Teacher, Maggie Stewart, attended Sunshine Circles training at the Theraplay Institute in Evanston, Illinois.

Sunshine Circles is an evidence-based social emotional development group that supports students to develop self control/regulation skills and address sensory and motor skill needs. Our teachers learned about promoting warm relationships between children and adults and friendships among peers. Emphasis is placed on cooperation between children and encouraging them to learn and practice self- control. Additionally, activities focus on building trust of others through concrete, personal and positive experiences and can help children with regulatory disorders and meeting tactile needs.

#WeAreClarkston

Reese M. really wants the elementary schools to begin earlier, so she took her petition straight to the top!

He said, “School start times are on the minds of many these days, and Reese made a strong argument for starting elementary school earlier. I’m looking forward to taking this back to my team and to our community for more feedback.”

Way to be a change-maker, Reese! #WeAreClarkston #SPEInspires

Clarkston Community Schools and Clarkston Education Association are partnering to celebrate universal "Well-Being Breaks" for all of our major holidays this year. One of our Four Pillars of Excellence in the district strategic plan centers on Whole Person Development. We believe school breaks should be just that - a brief reprieve from school responsibilities like homework, special projects, planning, and grading.

It is a time to reconnect with loved ones without the stress of school work creeping in. Therefore, all students AND staff will be free of academic-related work during the following breaks: Thanksgiving, Winter Break, Mid-Winter Break, and Spring Break

We hope you and your family consider the upcoming Winter Well-Being Break a chance to rest, reset, and return to school with renewed energy! #WeAreClarkston

Here's some Winter Wisdom for your Wednesday! Today we're offering a few reminders for keeping students and staff healthy during the cold and flu season:

Please discuss proper handwashing with your child and remind them that they should not share food or drinks with others.
Teach your child to sneeze or cough into their elbow or tissue.
If your child is ill, please keep them home.
If your child is running a fever, their temperature must be normal (98.6 degrees) for a 24 hour period before returning to school.
Please do not send medication to school. Staff cannot (by state law) dispense medication without a form signed by your doctor. This includes over the counter medication (ointments, cough drops, Tylenol, etc.). The forms can be found on our website under "Plan of Care" (https://www.clarkston.k12.mi.us/parents)

A doctor's note is required if your child has to stay indoors for recess. If your child is absent due to illness, please contact your school's attendance line.
